This report summarizes the results of the Off-Site Consequence Analysis (OCA) performed for the worst-case and alternate accidental release scenarios for a covered process using anhydrous ammonia located at the Seatex facility in Rosenberg, Fort Bend County, TX. The OCA was conducted in accordance with the requirements of EPA's Chemical Accidental Release Prevention Regulations found at 40 CFR 68.



Seatex will manufacture liquid fertilizer in batch reactors; the covered process of ammonium phosphate production uses anhydrous ammonia. The anhydrous ammonia is stored in a 15,000-gallon tank.



40 CFR 68.25 defines a worst-case scenario as the maximum quantity of the stored material released in 10 minutes, assuming no passive mitigation exists. The worst-case scenario will result in the largest distance to an endpoint specified in the 40 CFR Part 68 Appendix A.



The EPA-approved model, RMP*COMP, was used to model the worst case and alternate case scenarios to determine the distances to end-point concentrations. The end-point concentration for anhydrous ammonia is 0.14 mg/L, as specified in Appendix A, 40 CFR 68. 40 CFR 68.25(a)(2) specifies a worst-case scenario as the maximum quantity of the stored material that is released in 10 minutes, assuming no preventive and active mitigation exists. Following this guidance, the worst-case scenario distances to end point were determined.



The alternative case scenarios were also modeled based on the upper flow rate tolerance of the transfer line automatic shut-off valve. This means that a fracture with an equivalent diameter of up to 2.15 inches could occur without causing the valve to automatically shut-off. With these assumptions, the alternate case distances to end point were determined.



1.0 INTRODUCTION



This document was prepared in accordance with the EPA Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions 40 CFR Part 68, in particular, Subpart B Hazard Assessment, 40 CFR 68.20-42. Seatex operates a chemical blending and

packaging facility located at 445 Highway 36, Rosenberg, Fort Bend County, Texas. A fertilizer manufacturing unit adjacent to the existing facility at 239 Highway 36, Rosenberg, Fort Bend County, Texas is under construction. Ammonium phosphate will be produced using anhydrous ammonia in this new manufacturing unit. Certain measures to protect human health and the environment are specified for the equipment and in the standard operating procedures. This report summarizes the results of the Off-Site Consequence Analysis (OCA) performed for the worst-case and alternate accidental release scenarios for the covered processes.



Seatex will manufacture liquid fertilizer in batch reactors; the covered process of ammonium phosphate production uses anhydrous ammonia. The anhydrous ammonia is stored in a 15,000-gallon pressure tank.



2.0 DESCRIPTION OF RELEASE SCENARIOS



The worst-case release scenario and the alternative-case release scenario for the anhydrous ammonia storage tank were determined in accordance with ?68.25 and 68.28, respectively. The following is a description of the release scenarios and the meteorological data used in the modeling.



2.1 Worst-Case Release Scenario



The regulations require consideration of worst-case assumptions and allow no credit for preventive and active mitigation measures. The following discussion assumes the entire contents, 15,000 gallons (79,300 pounds) of the anhydrous ammonia tank released instantaneously. The discussions below, therefore, follow regulatory guidance and disregard any in-place safety measures.



The storage tank stores anhydrous ammonia under pressure. Anhydrous ammonia, with a boiling point of -28.03?F, is a gas at ambient temperature and pressure. The worst-case scenario models the instantaneous loss of the entire contents, 15,000 gallons of the anhydrous ammonia stored. Following EPA guidance on the worst-case OCA, the anhydrous ammonia is released at ground level as a vapor.



?68.22 specifies that t

he worst-case analysis shall use a wind speed of 1.5 meters per second and an "F" atmospheric stability class. The surface roughness factor used in the RMP*COMP model was assumed to be 0.5 m for the environment surrounding the facility.



2.1 Alternate-Case Release Scenario



The ambient temperature and wind speed used in the RMP*COMP model are 77?F (25?C) and 3.0 meters per second. An atmospheric stability class D and a relative humidity of 50 percent were used in this analysis.



3.0 MODELING ANALYSIS



The EPA dispersion model RMP*Comp was used to determine the distance to the endpoint for each scenario using chemical properties and meteorological data contained within the model. RMP*Comp uses set values for meteorological conditions like humidity, wind speed, temperature, and stability class. RMP*Comp follows the procedures set out in the OCA Guidance.



The input data and results of the consequence analyses for the worst-case scenarios are provided in Attachment A, and the input data and results for the alternate-case scenarios are provided in Attachment B, as summarized below.



3.1 Worst-Case Release Scenario



The worst-case scenario was modeled with the entire contents of the storage tank released in ten (10) minutes using the most stable atmospheric conditions.

3.2 Alternate-Case Release Scenario



The alternative case scenarios were also modeled based on the upper flow rate tolerance of the transfer line automatic shut-off valve. This means that a fracture with an equivalent diameter of up to 2.15 inches could occur without causing the valve to automatically close.

Utilizing the dispersion distance to the worst-case scenario end-point distances, the off-site population impact was determined in a

ccordance with 40 CFR 68.30. The evaluation determined that the worst-case accidental release will have an impact on the immediate population. Institutions such as schools and hospitals, as well as parks and recreational areas, are located within the predicted end-point distance. These areas were identified by using the USGS Topo Map for the Rosenberg area included in Attachment C.

5.0 INCIDENT PREVENTION



5.1 Process Safety Information



Seatex utilizes an enterprise resource and planning (ERP) system, which will henceforth be referred to a Chempax, that maintains batch information for the various liquid ammonium phosphate fertilizers blended in the facility.  By utilizing Chempax the Supply Chain, Technology, Production, and EHS&S departments can plan batch operations utilizing bills of lading from shipping and receiving, using batch tickets detailing blend instructions, and track operational usage. Chempax also serves as a redundant repository for our safe operating procedures (SOPs) and safety data sheets (SDSs).



A new product review (NPR) process of introducing and evaluating new chemicals initiates the use of batch instructions and provides a list of component and finished product SDSs. The NPR process engages Sales as the customer contact that clarifies any safety or process requirements, Technology tests and evaluates the feasibility of produ

cing the product, and the Industrial Hygienist in the EHSS group provides guidance in the safe handling of a new product.



Batch information from Chempax transitions to EHS Insight, a cloud-based environmental health and safety (EHS) management system that serves as the repository for compliance documents. These documents include but are not limited to SDSs, near miss and incident reports, incident and near miss investigations, and chronicles new product reviews and industrial hygiene monitoring. EHS Insight also utilizes applications covering management of change and corrective actions.



The facility also maintains documentation that provides information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure, temperature ratings, and electrical rating of equipment. This information provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as evaluating proposed changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.



5.2 Process Hazard Analysis



The Seatex 239 facility has a comprehensive program to help ensure hazards associated with the process are identified and controlled. Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.



The Seatex 239 facility primarily uses the Management of Change and the Job Safety Analysis (JSA) for evaluating potential hazards. These evaluations provide  Operators and Supervisors with an understanding of the processes and logistics in production. The team identifies and evaluates potential hazards and develops a plan to mitigate those risks. The JSA uses a color-coded risk ranking for potential accident scenarios: red for highest risk; orange for significant risk and yellow for low risk that calls for caution. JSAs and MOCs are retained in the EHS Insight Management System.



5.3 Operating Procedures



Seatex main

tains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) initial startup of a new process. These procedures are periodically reviewed to maintain correctness and annually certified as current and accurate. In addition, procedures include key process parameters and guidance on how to respond to upper or lower limit exceedance for specific process or equipment parameters. This information, along with written operating procedures, is readily available in the facility for operators and other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job tasks. Refer to the Seatex PSM Manual.



5.4 Training



To complement the written procedures for process operations, Seatex has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process. New employees receive basic training in facility operations if they are not already familiar with such operations. An experienced operator will mentor new employees with blending operations, truck charging or discharging, and drum and tote filling. In addition, all operators periodically train on the operating procedures, MOCs, JSAs and Lessons Learned from incidents or near misses. All training is documented for each operator and filed in the Seatex shared drive or on EHS Insight.



5.5 Mechanical Integrity



Seatex has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures. These activities are based on ANSI/CGA 2.1 "Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia" and other r

elevant RAGAGEP. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process.



Personnel who perform maintenance activities receive training on (1) an overview of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) emergency response plans, and (5) applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their jobs in a safe manner.



Job plans/written procedures/checklists help ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training. Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels). If a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service (if possible), or a management of change team will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to ensure the safe operation of the equipment.



Another integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance. Seatex incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs. This helps ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made. Refer to the Seatex PSM Manual.



5.6 Management of Change (MOC)



Seatex has implemented an MOC process to cover operational and process changes as the result of plant expansions. Employees (operators), supervisors, EHSS, and leadership continue to review equipment upgrades and the processes for streamlining production. Changes are reviewed to (1) ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and to (2) verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change. Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment and facility information, as well as procedures, are updated

to incorporate these changes.



5.7 Pre-Startup Review



Seatex conducts a Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) for any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service. Maintenance reviews and verifies the soundness of construction in accordance with design specifications and mechanical / electrical codes. The MOC underpins the PSSR with field verification of process equipment and procedures essential in implementing related safeguards.



5.8 Compliance Audits



A compliance audit addressing all OSHA PSM and EPA RMP requirements is conducted at least every three years. The audit team documents findings, develops recommendations, and provides the overall results to facility management in a written report. All corrective actions are tracked until they are completed, and the two most recent audit reports are retained at the facility in EHS Insight. Refer to the Seatex PSM Manual.



5.9 Third-Party Audits



In the event of a release of ammonia that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury, as required by RMP regulations, Seatex will retain the services of a third-party to complete the next scheduled compliance audit as required by 40 CFR 68.80. Refer to the Seatex PSM Manual.



5.10 Incident investigation



Seatex promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. Most important, Seatex conducts investigations of significant near misses that could potentially result in a major event. The goal of each investigation is to determine the causes of the incident and develop corrective actions. The investigation team docume

nts its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to facility management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) in the form of Lessons Learned delivered in the monthly safety training. Incident investigation reports are retained in the EHS Insight Management System for future reference when reviewing past events or expanding operations to ensure that similar events and near misses do not occur.



5.11 Employee Participation



Seatex Operators participate in all aspects of Process Safety Management (PSM) and accident prevention. Examples of employee participation range from updating operating procedures and other documents to participating in the industrial hygiene program aimed at evaluating potential exposures to hazardous chemical. Industrial hygiene reports have documented best practices and enhancements to lower and eliminate potential exposures. These reports chronicle the lessons learned and continual improvements implemented by Operations. Employees are informed of their potential exposures when using personal protection, best practices and engineering controls.



5.12 Hot Work Permit



Metal cutting, grinding, oxygen-fuel gas cutting, brazing, and welding are considered "hot work". Any time hot work is to be performed on or near a covered process, a written hot work permit must be generated by either employees or outside contractors, as required under Occupational Health & Safety Administration (OSHA) 1910.119(k). All Hot Work Permits must be reviewed, approved and closed out by the PSM/RMP Coordinator or Director or above, to ensure understanding of work to be completed. Refer to the Seatex PSM Manual.



5.13 Contractors



Seatex uses contractors t

o supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the facility has procedures in place to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform facility personnel of any hazards that they find during their work. This is accomplished by providing contractors with (1) a process overview, (2) information about safety and health hazards, (3) emergency response plan requirements, and (4) safe work practices prior to their beginning work. In addition, Seatex has a program in place to evaluate contractor safety programs and performance. Facility personnel closely monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations. Refer to the Seatex PSM Manual.



6.0 OFF-SITE ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ANALYSIS



Environmentally sensitive receptors were identified within the areas potentially impacted by the worst-case and alternate-case release scenario. U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) maps were utilized to identify the receptors. The following lists the potentially impacted areas:

7.0 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The covered processes are under construction and therefore, there have been no accidental releases from the covered processes in the last five years.



SUMMARY



An Off-Site Consequence Analysis (OCA) was performed for the covered processes at the Seatex Rosenberg facility. The release scenarios were modeled utilizing EPA RMP*Comp.



Residential and

environmentally sensitive areas have a potential to be affected by an accidental release.



Safeguards considered for the covered processes which would act to further reduce the impacted areas include the following:

? The Safety Systems will receive regular testing to ensure operational status;

? The storage tank will be protected by physical barriers to prevent structure damage thereby reducing the likelihood of a puncture of the tank; and

? Response by the plant personnel would reduce the total quantity and/or release rate of an incident.

? Familiarization of the facility and operational procedures will be extended to the Local Emergency Planning Committee and the Rosenberg Emergency Response personnel to respond to a release is conducted periodically.
